text: Canadian singer and songwriter Carly Rae Jepsen has received 29 awards from 71 nominations, including an American Music Award, four Billboard Music Awards, three Juno Awards, three Much Music Video Awards and two Teen Choice Awards. In 2007, Jepsen placed third in Canadian Idol season five's competition. Before signing with Interscope, in 2008 she independently released her debut album, Tug of War, which its eponymous lead single won the award for Song of the Year at the 2010 Canadian Radio Music Awards. Her second album, title Kiss (2012), won two awards at the 2013 Juno Awards, winning the Album of the Year. The first single, "Call Me Maybe", was nominated for two Grammy Awards and won several other accolades, including the Billboard Music Award, MuchMusic Video Award and MTV Europe Music Award. Jepsen's collaboration with Owl City, "Good Time", won two Billboard Japan Music Awards. ==American Music Awards== The American Music Awards (AMAs) is an annual American music awards show, created by Dick Clark in 1973. {| width="80%" class="wikitable" |- ! style="width:10%;"| Year ! style="width:40%;"| Category ! style="width:35%;"| Recipient ! style="width:15%;"| Result ! |- |align="center"| 2012 | New Artist of the Year | Carly Rae Jepsen | | style="text-align:center;"| |} ==Billboard Awards== ===Billboard Music Awards=== The Billboard Music Awards was discontinued in 2007, but returned in 2011. {| width="80%" class="wikitable" |- ! style="width:10%;"| Year ! style="width:40%;"| Category ! style="width:35%;"| Nominated work / recipient ! style="width:15%;"| Result ! |- | rowspan="8" style="text-align:center;"|2013 | Top Pop Song of the Year | rowspan="5"|"Call Me Maybe" | | rowspan="8" style="text-align:center;"| |- | Top Digital Song | |- | Hot 100 Song | |- | Top Radio Song | |- | Top Streaming Song | |- | Top New Artist | rowspan="3"|Carly Rae Jepsen | |- | Top Female Artist | |- | Top Digital Songs Artist | |} ===Billboard Japan Music Awards=== Founded by Billboard Japan, the Billboard Japan Music Awards honor artists, both Japanese and foreign, who had achieved best results in Billboard Japan charts. {| width="80%" class="wikitable" |- ! style="width:10%;"| Year ! style="width:40%;"| Category ! style="width:35%;"| Nominated work ! style="width:15%;"| Result ! |- | rowspan="2" style="text-align:center;"| 2012 | Hot Top Airplay of the Year | rowspan="2"|"Good Time" | | style="text- align:center;"| |- | Digital & Airplay Overseas of the Year | | style="text- align:center;"| |} ===Billboard's Women in Music Awards=== Billboard's Women in Music Awards is a ceremony held annually by Billboard to honor influential female artists and music executives. {| width="80%" class="wikitable" |- ! style="width:10%;"| Year ! style="width:40%;"| Category ! style="width:35%;"| Recipient ! style="width:15%;"| Result ! |- | 2012 | Rising Star | Carly Rae Jepsen | | style="text-align:center;"| |} ==BreakTudo Awards== The BreakTudo Awards is a Brazilian awards show to honour the year's biggest achievements in music, film, television and more. Mendes has received two awards. {| width="80%" class="wikitable" |- ! style="width:10%;"| Year ! style="width:40%;"| Category ! style="width:35%;"| Recipient ! style="width:15%;"| Result ! |- |align="center"|2019 | Album of the Year | Dedicated | | style="text- align:center;"|https://www.allkpop.com/article/2019/08/breaktudo- awards-2019-blackpink-bts-and-red-velvet-received-multiple-nominations |} ==Canada's Walk of Fame== Canada's Walk of Fame, located in Toronto, Ontario, Canada, is a walk of fame that acknowledges the achievements and accomplishments of successful Canadians. First awarded in 2010, the Allan Slaight Award is awarded to young Canadians for making a positive impact in the fields of music, film, literature, visual or performing arts, sports, innovation or philanthropy." Recipients receive an honorarium of $10,000 from the Slaight Foundation, but are not considered inductees of the Walk of Fame. {| width="80%" class="wikitable" |- ! style="width:10%;"| Year ! style="width:40%;"| Category ! style="width:35%;"| Recipient ! style="width:15%;"| Result ! |- |align="center"| 2013 | Slaight Allan Awards | Carly Rae Jepsen | | style="text-align:center;"| |} ==Canadian Radio Music Awards== The Canadian Radio Music Awards is an annual series of awards presented by the Canadian Association of Broadcasters that are part of Canadian Music Week. {| width="80%" class="wikitable" |- ! style="width:10%;"| Year ! style="width:40%;"| Category ! style="width:35%;"| Nominated work ! style="width:15%;"| Result ! |- |align="center"| 2010 | Song of the Year | "Tug of War" | | style="text-align:center;"| |} ==Grammy Awards== The Grammy Awards is an accolade by the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences (NARAS) of the United States to recognize outstanding achievement in the music industry. It shares recognition of the music industry as that of the other performance arts: Emmy Awards (television), the Tony Awards (stage performance), and the Academy Awards (motion pictures). {| width="80%" class="wikitable" |- ! style="width:10%;"| Year ! style="width:40%;"| Category ! style="width:35%;"| Nominated work ! style="width:15%;"| Result ! |- | rowspan="2" style="text-align:center;"| 2013 | Song of the Year | rowspan="2"|"Call Me Maybe" | | rowspan="2" style="text-align:center;"| |- | Best Pop Solo Performance | |} ==Juno Awards== The Juno Awards is presented annually to Canadian musical artists and bands to acknowledge their artistic and technical achievements in all aspects of music. New members of the Canadian Music Hall of Fame are also inducted as part of the awards ceremonies. {| width="80%" class="wikitable" |- ! style="width:10%;"| Year ! style="width:40%;"| Category ! style="width:35%;"| Nominated work / recipient ! style="width:15%;"| Result ! |- | rowspan="2" style="text- align:center;"|2010 | Breakthrough Artist of the Year | Carly Rae Jepsen | | style="text-align:center;"| |- | Songwriter of the Year | Carly Rae Jepsen ("Tug of War", "Bucket", "Money and the Ego") | | style="text-align:center;"| |- | rowspan="5" style="text-align:center;"|2013 | Single of the Year | "Call Me Maybe" | | rowspan="5" style="text-align:center;"| |- | Album of the Year | rowspan="2"|Kiss | |- | Pop Album of the Year | |- | Artist of the Year | rowspan="2"|Carly Rae Jepsen | |- | Fan Choice Award | |- | rowspan="5" style="text-align:center;"|2016 | Fan Choice Award | rowspan="2"|Carly Rae Jepsen | | |} ==Los Premios 40 Principales== Los Premios 40 Principales is an award presented by the musical radio station Los 40 Principales. It was created in 2006 as part of the celebrations for their fortieth anniversary. {| width="80%" class="wikitable" |- ! style="width:10%;"| Year ! style="width:40%;"| Category ! style="width:35%;"| Nominated work / recipient ! style="width:15%;"| Result ! |- | rowspan="2" style="text- align:center;"|2012 | Best International Song | "Call Me Maybe" | | rowspan="2" style="text-align:center;"| |- | Best International New Artist | Carly Rae Jepsen | |} ==Los Premios 40 Principales América== The American edition of Los Premios 40 Principales, established in 2012. {| width="80%" class="wikitable" |- ! style="width:10%;"| Year ! style="width:40%;"| Category ! style="width:35%;"| Nominated work / recipient ! style="width:15%;"| Result ! |- | rowspan="2" style="text-align:center;"|2012 | Best International Song | "Call Me Maybe" | | rowspan="2" style="text-align:center;"| |- | Best International New Artist | Carly Rae Jepsen | |} ==MuchMusic Video Awards== The Much Music Video Awards (MMVAs), originally named the Canadian Music Video Awards before 1995 is an annual awards presented by the Canadian TV channel Much to honour the year's best music videos. {| width="80%" class="wikitable" |- ! style="width:10%;"| Year ! style="width:40%;"| Category ! style="width:35%;"| Nominated work / recipient ! style="width:15%;"| Result ! |- |style="text-align:center;"|2010 | UR Fave: New Artist | "Bucket" | | style="text-align:center;"| |- | rowspan="4" style="text-align:center;"|2012 | UR Fave Artist | Carly Rae Jepsen | | style="text-align:center;"| |- | Most Streamed Video of the Year | rowspan="3"|"Call Me Maybe" | | style="text- align:center;"| |- | Video of the Year | | style="text-align:center;"| |- | UR Fave Video | | style="text-align:center;"| |- | rowspan="2" style="text- align:center;"|2013 | International Video of the Year by a Canadian | "This Kiss" | | rowspan="2" style="text-align:center;"| |- | Your Fave Artist/Group | rowspan="2"|Carly Rae Jepsen | |- |align="center"| 2015 | Fan Fave Artist or Group | | style="text-align:center;"| |} ==MTV Awards== ===MTV Video Music Awards=== An MTV Video Music Awards (commonly abbreviated as VMA) is an award presented by the cable channel MTV to honor the best music videos of the year. Originally conceived as an alternative to the Grammy Awards (in the video category), the annual MTV Video Music Awards ceremony has often been called the "Super Bowl for youth". The statue given to winners is an astronaut on the moon, one of the earliest representations of MTV, and colloquially called a "moonman". Jepsen was nominated twice. {| width="80%" class="wikitable" |- ! style="width:10%;"| Year ! style="width:40%;"| Category ! style="width:35%;"| Nominated work / recipient ! style="width:15%;"| Result ! |- | rowspan="2" style="text-align:center;"|2012 | Best New Artist | "Call Me Maybe" / Carly Rae Jepsen | | style="text-align:center;"| |- | Most Share-Worthy Video | "Call Me Maybe" | | style="text-align:center;"| |} ===MTV Movie & TV Awards=== An MTV Movie & TV Awards is an award presented by the cable channel MTV to honor the best on cinema and television of the year. {| width="80%" class="wikitable" |- ! style="width:10%;"| Year ! style="width:40%;"| Category ! style="width:35%;"| Nominated work / recipient ! style="width:15%;"| Result ! |- | rowspan="1" style="text-align:center;"|2017 | Best Musical Moment |"You're the One That I Want" | | |} ===MTV Europe Music Awards=== The MTV Europe Music Awards (EMA) is presented by MTV Networks Europe which awards prizes to musicians and performers. Originally conceived as an alternative to the MTV Video Music Awards and since 2011 other worldwide, regional nominations have been added. {| width="80%" class="wikitable" |- ! style="width:10%;"| Year ! style="width:40%;"| Category ! style="width:35%;"| Nominated work / recipient ! style="width:15%;"| Result ! |- | rowspan="4" style="text-align:center;"|2012 | Best Song | "Call Me Maybe" | | rowspan="4" style="text-align:center;"| |- | Best Push Act | rowspan="3"|Carly Rae Jepsen | |- | Best New Act | |- |Best North American Act | |- |style="text- align:center;"|2015 | rowspan=2|Best Canadian Act | rowspan=2|Carly Rae Jepsen | | http://www.mtv.com/news/2360044/2015-ema-winners-list/ |- |style="text- align:center;"|2019 | |https://www.mtvema.com/pt-pt/noticias/qcfvct/drumroll- please-meet-your-2019-mtv-ema-nominees |} ===MTV Video Music Awards Japan=== The MTV Video Music Awards Japan is the Japanese version of the MTV Video Music Awards. {| width="80%" class="wikitable" |- ! style="width:10%;"| Year ! style="width:40%;"| Category ! style="width:35%;"| Nominated work / recipient ! style="width:15%;"| Result ! |- | rowspan="2" style="text- align:center;"|2013 | Best New Artist |"Call Me Maybe" | | rowspan="2" style="text-align:center;"| |- | Album of the Year |Kiss | |- | style="text- align:center;"|2015 | Best Female Video | "I Really Like You" | |} ==Nickelodeon Kids' Choice Awards== The Nickelodeon Kids' Choice Awards, is an annual awards show that airs on the Nickelodeon cable channel, which honors the year's biggest television, movie, and music acts, as voted by Nickelodeon viewers. {| width="80%" class="wikitable" |- ! style="width:10%;"| Year ! style="width:40%;"| Category ! style="width:35%;"| Nominated work ! style="width:15%;"| Result ! |- |align="center"| 2013 | Favorite Song | "Call Me Maybe" | | style="text-align:center;"| |} ==NRJ Music Award== The NRJ Music Awards is an award presented by the French radio station NRJ to honor the best in the French and worldwide music industry. {| width="80%" class="wikitable" |- ! style="width:10%;"| Year ! style="width:40%;"| Category ! style="width:35%;"| Nominated work / recipient ! style="width:15%;"| Result ! |- | rowspan="3" align="center"| 2012 | International Breakthrough of the Year | Carly Rae Jepsen | | style="text-align:center;"|Rihanna and Bruno Mars among NRJ Awards winners |- | International Song of the Year | "Call Me Maybe" | |- | International Group/Duo of the Year | Owly City & Carly Rae Jepsen | |} ==People's Choice Awards== The People's Choice Awards is an American awards show, recognizing the people and the work of popular culture, voted on by the general public. {| width="80%" class="wikitable" |- ! style="width:10%;"| Year ! style="width:40%;"| Category ! style="width:35%;"| Nominated work / recipient ! style="width:15%;"| Result ! |- | rowspan="3" style="text- align:center;"|2013 | Favorite Song of the Year | rowspan="2"|"Call Me Maybe" | | rowspan="3" style="text-align:center;"| |- | Favorite Music Video | |- | Carly Rae Jepsen | Favorite Breakout Artist | |} ==Polaris Music Prize== The Polaris Music Prize is a Canadian awards show, recognizing artistic merit, regardless of genre, sales, or record label, voted on by the journalists and music critics. {| width="80%" class="wikitable" |- ! style="width:10%;"| Year ! style="width:40%;"| Category ! style="width:35%;"| Nominated work / recipient ! style="width:15%;"| Result ! |- | rowspan="2" style="text- align:center;"|2016 | Shortlist | rowspan="2"|Emotion | | rowspan="1" style="text-align:center;"| "Kaytranada wins 2016 Polaris Music Prize for his album 99.9%". The Globe and Mail, September 19, 2016. |- | Longlist | | rowspan="1" style="text-align:center;"|"Polaris Music Prize reveals the 200-plus albums on this year’s 'longer list'". CBC Music, August 29, 2016. |- | rowspan="1" style="text-align:center;"|2017 | rowspan=2|Longlist | rowspan="1"|Emotion: Side B | | rowspan="1" style="text-align:center;"| "The 2017 Polaris Music Prize Long List Is Here". Polaris Music Prize , July 13, 2017. |- | rowspan="1" style="text-align:center;"|2019 | Dedicated | |rowspan="1" style="text-align:center;"|https://pitchfork.com/news/polaris- prize-2019-long-list-announced-carly-rae-jepsen-marie-davidson-fucked-up-more/ |} ==Rober Awards Music Poll== {| width="80%" class="wikitable" |- ! style="width:10%;"| Year ! style="width:40%;"| Category ! style="width:35%;"| Nominated work / recipient ! style="width:15%;"| Result ! |- | rowspan=2|2015 | Best Pop | rowspan=3|Carly Rae Jepsen | | rowspan=2|https://roberawards.com/awards-archive/2015-the-year-in-music/the- rober-awards-2015-music-poll/ |- | rowspan=2|Guilty Pleasure | |- | 2016 | | https://roberawards.com/awards-archive/2016-the-year-in-music/the-rober- awards-2016-music-poll/ ==SOCAN Awards== The SOCAN (the Society of Composers, Authors and Music Publishers of Canada) is the Canadian copyright collective for the right to communicate to the public and publicly perform musical works. SOCAN administers these rights on behalf of its members (composers, lyricists, songwriters, and their publishers) and those of affiliated international organizations by licensing the use of their music in Canada. {| width="80%" class="wikitable" |- ! style="width:10%;"| Year ! style="width:40%;"| Category ! style="width:35%;"| Nominated work ! style="width:15%;"| Result ! |- | style="text-align:center;"|2014 |International Achievement Award |rowspan=2|"Call Me Maybe" | | style="text-align:center;"|25th Anniversary SOCAN Awards celebrate Canada’s immense achievements in music creation . SOCAN.CA (June 17, 2014). Retrieved on 2015-08-20. |- | style="text- align:center;"|2019 | Most Performed Song in SOCAN History | |style="text- align:center;"|https://www.socan.com/2019/ |} ==SiriusXM Indies Awards== The SiriusXM Indies Awards are awarded to recognize Canadian and international artists in independent music sector. {| width="80%" class="wikitable" |- ! style="width:10%;"| Year ! style="width:40%;"| Category ! style="width:35%;"| Nominated work / recipient ! style="width:15%;"| Result ! |- !scope="row" rowspan="8"|2013 |Single of the Year | rowspan="2"| "Call Me Maybe" | | style="text-align:center;" rowspan="8"| |- |Video of the Year | |- |Artist of the Year | rowspan="5"| Carly Rae Jepsen | |- |Most Played Independent Artist or Group of the Year | |- |Female Artist of the Year | |- |Pop Artist or Group of the Year | |- |Most Follow Artist of the Year | |- |Best-Selling Independent Release of the Year |Kiss | |- |} ==Teen Choice Awards== The Teen Choice Awards is an annual awards show that airs on Fox television network. The awards honor the year's biggest achievements in music, movies, sports, television, fashion, and more, voted by teen viewers (ages 13 to 19). Winners receive a full size surfboard designed with the graphics of that year's show. {| width="80%" class="wikitable" |- ! style="width:10%;"| Year ! style="width:40%;"| Category ! style="width:35%;"| Nominated work / recipient ! style="width:15%;"| Result ! |- | rowspan="3" style="text- align:center;"|2012 | Choice: Summer Song | "Call Me Maybe" | | style="text- align:center;"| |- | Choice: Breakout Artist | rowspan="2"|Carly Rae Jepsen | | style="text-align:center;"| |- | Choice: Music Star Female | | style="text- align:center;"| |} ==Western Canadian Music Awards== The Western Canadian Music Awards (WCMAs) are an annual awards event for music in the western portion of Canada. The awards are provided by the Western Canada Music Alliance, the award presentation gala takes place on the final evening of the Breakout West music conference & festival, which takes place in a different Western Canadian city each year. {| width="80%" class="wikitable" |- ! style="width:10%;"| Year ! style="width:40%;"| Category ! style="width:35%;"| Nominated work ! style="width:15%;"| Result ! |- |align="center"| 2010 | Song of the Year | "Tug of War" | | style="text-align:center;"|Jepsen's MySpace Blog January 27, 2010. Blogs.myspace.com (January 27, 2010). Retrieved on April 16, 2012. |- |align="center"| 2012 | Pop Recording of the Year | "Curiosity" | | style="text-align:center;"| |} ==World Music Awards== The World Music Awards is an annual international awards show founded in 1989 that honours recording artists based on worldwide sales figures provided by the International Federation of the Phonographic Industry (IFPI). {| width="80%" class="wikitable" |- ! style="width:10%;"| Year ! style="width:40%;"| Category ! style="width:35%;"| Nominated work / recipient ! style="width:15%;"| Result ! |- |align="center" rowspan="2"| 2014 | World's Best Video | "Call Me Maybe" | | style="text-align:center;"| |- | World's Best Entertainer of the Year | Carly Rae Jepsen | | style="text-align:center;"| |} ==References== Jepsen, Carly Rae Awards
title: List of awards and nominations received by Carly Rae Jepsen
